files.patch:
@@ -58,5 +58,12 @@
-# Note: In the latter case, the file profile.security must exist and may
-# define a default security profile or be empty. Other files such as
-# profileFIPS.security may exist in the same directory and define alternative
-# profiles. To switch to an alternative profile on a per-execution basis,
-# a user can launch Java passing an argument such as -DSecurityProfile=FIPS.
+# Note: In the latter case, the SecurityProfile system property can be set to
+# select an existing security profile on a per-execution basis. For example,
+# if Java is launched with the argument -DSecurityProfile=FIPS, the profile
+# defined in the profileFIPS.security file is applied or an error thrown if
+# not found. Other files may exist in the same directory defining alternative
+# profiles. If SecurityProfile is not set, it expands to the empty string.
+# When a profile.security file exists (may be empty), it defines a default
+# security profile. When it does not exist, an error is thrown and explicit
+# profile selection is required. Security properties defined after an include
+# statement will override any matching property defined in a profile. In order
+# to avoid this behavior, the include statement may be placed at the end of
+# this file.
